This IRM contains policies and procedures for non-tax debt collection.

1.36.4.1.1(1)(2)(3), Background, modiﬁed the background section to reﬂect clearer applicable and explanations in simpler terms which deﬁne the debt collection program.

IRM 1.36.4.1.3.2(c), Associate CFO for Financial Management and Deputy Associate CFO for Administrative Financial Management, moved Annual Certiﬁcation Agreement responsibility to Government Payables and Funds Management and added the responsibility of AWG Hearing

IRM 1.36.4.1.3.5(d)(e)(f), Government Payables and Funds Management, moved Fiscal Service debt submission to Intragovernmental and Funds Processing, added Annual Certiﬁcation Agreement responsibility from associate CFO for FM and deputy associate CFO for AFM responsibilities, added Salary Offset Hearing Requests, AWG Hearings requests, 1099-C processing and Chief Counsel consults responsibilities from Intragovernmental and Funds Management. These are a shift in responsibilities due to the CFO reorganizational change in 2021.

IRM 1.36.4.1.3.6, Intragovernmental and Funds Processing, deleted the referral to Workforce Relations Division (WRD) of employees with delinquent debts. This is listed in 1.36.4.1.3.8 for Resources Shared Services.

IRM 1.36.4.1.3.8, Human Resources and Shared Services, deleted the consults with Chief Counsel before suspending or terminating collection activity since the HRSS director has this authority. Deleted the consult with Chief Counsel before continuing collection activities on debtors that have ﬁled bankruptcy since HCO debt collection is handled through USDA National Finance Center have their own protocols for handling bankruptcies.
IRM 1.36.4.3(1)(e), Debts arising from other various actions, added Vendor Transactions since administrative (non-tax) debt does not apply to only employees and former employees.
IRM 4.36.4.3.5, Vendor Transactions, this section added to address potential debts generated from those other than employees and former employees.

a. Added minor editorial changes. b. EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS IRM 1.36.4, dated May 04, 2020, is superseded.
All business units
Teresa R. Hunter Chief Financial Officer
Table of Contents
(Non-tax) Debt Management
page (
) Purpose: Provides processes and guidance for the collection of administrative (non-tax) debt owed to the IRS by employees, former employees and entities. (
) Audience: All current and former IRS employees and entities (also referred to as debtors) that owe non-tax debts to the IRS. (
) Policy Owner: CFO (
) Program Owners: CFO Government Payables and Funds Management office and HCO. (
) Primary Stakeholders: Employees, former employees, estates of former employees and entities that have incurred non-tax debts to the IRS. (
) Program Goals: Ensure non-tax debts owed to the IRS are resolved equitably and timely. (
) The Debt Collection Act of
and the Debt Collection Improvement Act of

were enacted to: • Increase efficiency of governmentwide efforts to collect debts owed to the United States. • Maximize collections of delinquent debt. • Minimize costs and reduce loss arising from debt management. • Ensure the public is fully informed of the federal government’s debt lection policies. • Ensure debtors have all appropriate due process rights. (

) This IRM contains provisions pertaining to non-tax debts owed to the United States government by individuals and entities such as businesses, trade ciations and non-proﬁt organizations. These provisions derive their authority from Chapter
of Title
United States Code (USC) and from Title
Parts
and

, of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR). This IRM also contains provisions speciﬁcally pertaining to non-tax debts owed to the United States government by federal civilian employees, former federal civilian employees and by the estates of former federal employees. These provisions derive their authority from Title
of the USC and from Title
of the CFR. (
) Title
, USC

, Collection and compromise, requires a federal agency to try to collect claims of or debts owed to the United States government for money or property arising out of the activities of, or referred to, the agency. (

1.36.4.1.3 (08-04-2022) Responsibilities
The Associate CFO for Financial Management and the Deputy Associate CFO for Administrative Financial Management are responsible for:
Overseeing the administrative (non-tax) debt collection process. Submitting requests for legal opinions to Chief Counsel concerning whether termination and/or close out of debts is appropriate.
(Non-tax) Debt Management 1.36.4
Serving as a hearing official for administrative wage garnishment hearing requests from former employees.
a. Overseeing the Travel and Relocation submission of debts. b. Providing review of or proof of debt when request by a
Government Payables and Funds Management is responsible for:

a. Overseeing the processing, collection and accounting of all (non-tax) debts except for those that HCO has responsibility. b. Reviewing and recommending action for administrative (non-tax) debts submitted for termination of collection and write-off. c. Overseeing the negotiation and ﬁnalization of inter-agency agreements for obtaining non-Treasury hearing officials for salary offset hearings. d. Certifying and signing the Annual Certiﬁcation Agreement for debt tion services under the Fiscal Service Cross-Servicing program and Treasury Offset program. e. Referring requests for petition of salary offset hearings to the non- Treasury hearing official and Administrative Wage Garnishment (AWG) hearing requests to the IRS hearing official. f. Providing data for processing Form

-C, Cancellation of Debt. g. Consulting with Chief Counsel (General Legal Services) before ing or terminating collection activity for debts of deceased employees former employees. h. Consulting with Chief Counsel (General Legal Services) before collection activities on debtors that have ﬁled bankruptcy.
Consulting with Chief Counsel (General Legal Services) before continuing collection activities on debtors that have ﬁled bankruptcy.
(08-04-2022) Intragovernmental and Funds Processing
Managing the processing, collection and accounting for (non

tax) debts, including posting and applying payments not by HCO. Issuing debt letters and other correspondence for indebtedness for taxes and salary, leave and beneﬁts debts. Referring requests for petition for salary offset hearings to Payables and Funds Management office. Referring debtor requests for review of debt to appropriate office. Serving as the deciding official on repayment agreements and hardship. Referring voluntary repayment agreements and delinquent (non
tax) employee debts to the National Finance Center (NFC) for offset. Referring delinquent administrative (non
tax) debts for former and entities to Fiscal Service for collection action.
delinquent administrative (non-tax) debts for former entities to Fiscal Service for collection action.

The Associate Chief Counsel (Finance and Management) is responsible for overseeing the debt collection program involving Chief Counsel employees.

Overseeing the salary, leave and health beneﬁts debt collection program for Chief Counsel employees. Serving as the deciding official on repayment agreements and ﬁnancial hardship considerations requested by Chief Counsel employees.
Administrative (Non-tax) Debt Management 1.36.4

a. Managing the collection and processing of and accounting for salary, leave and health beneﬁts debts. b. Ensuring debt is correctly established in the NFC Administrative and Collection (ABCO) System. c. Issuing debt letters and other correspondence for indebtedness for leave and health beneﬁts debts. d. Receiving debtor requests for salary offset hearings and referring the requests to the Associate Chief Counsel (Finance and Management). e. Recommending actions for administrative debts submitted for of collection and/or write
off. f. Consulting with Chief Counsel (Finance and Management) before sus

pending or terminating collection activity for debts of deceased and former employees. g. Referring employees with delinquent debts to the Director, Labor and Employee Relations (LER) division within Chief Counsel for any ate disciplinary action.

a. Validating time and attendance records for accuracy. b. Initiating Time & Attendance (T&A) corrections. c. Examining and certifying travel vouchers for accuracy. d. Initiating timely and accurate personnel action requests. e. Reporting errors immediately to the applicable program office. f. Reinforcing IRS’s requirements for ﬁnancial responsibility.
Employees and former IRS employees are responsible for responding timely to debt letters and paying all undisputed administrative debts.
The IRS must execute a certiﬁcation agreement annually to Treasury delinquent non

tax debts referred to Treasury for collection purposes were valid and legally enforceable. HCO Austin Payroll Center uses the Payroll and Personnel Systems (PPS) Measures Dashboard Report to determine if the IRS is collecting non
tax debts owed and to identify outreach opportunities that could prevent debt creation.

Program controls for administrative non-tax debts owed to the IRS include:

Control Control Method Validations All requests for accounts receivable contain dual levels of approval from the requesting area prior to submission to the Debt Collection Unit to ensure validity of the debt. Dual levels of approval are also completed by the Intragovernmental and Funds Processing section before and after establishment to ensure accuracy and completeness. Documentation/Retention The applicable business unit maintains all supporting documentation. Government Payables and Funds Management ensures the inclusion of the supporting documentation with the account receiv- able request and maintains both in their ﬁles.

Control Control Method Validations All requests for accounts receivable contain dual levels of approval from the requesting area prior to submission to the Debt Collection Unit to ensure validity of the debt. Dual levels of approval are also completed by the Intragovernmental and Funds Processing section before and after establishment to ensure accuracy and completeness. Documentation/Retention The applicable business unit maintains all supporting documentation. Government Payables and Funds Management ensures the inclusion of the supporting documentation with the account receiv
able request and maintains both in their ﬁles.
The applicable business unit maintains supporting documentation. Government Payables and Funds Management ensures the inclusion of the supporting documentation with the account receiv
able request and maintains both in their ﬁles.
Administrative (Non-tax) Debt Management

Reporting Monthly reports are provided to the Gov- ernment Payables and Funds Management director and section chiefs on the status of open debt to monitor aging debt and to ensure delinquent debts are submitted to Fiscal Service’s Debt Management Services or NFC timely. Conﬁdential Data HCO and Government Payables and Funds Management use restricted access sites to store employee debt information.

The following terms and deﬁnitions apply to this program: a. Account receivable - An amount owed to the government by an indi- vidual organization or other entity to satisfy an administrative (non-tax) debt or claim. b. Administrative debt - A debt that occurs because of administrative actions. c. Administrative Fee - Additional costs incurred in processing and handling a debt because it has become delinquent. d. Administrative wage garnishment (AWG) - The withholding of a of a debtor’s non-federal pay to satisfy an administrative (non-tax) debt owed to the IRS. e. Appeal - An administrative proceeding in which the debtor requests a higher management official review of the determination that they owe or part of the debt. f. Automatic stay - The statutory court order that prohibits the of the Treasury from pursuing further collection action against the while the debtor’s bankruptcy is pending. g. Bankruptcy - A legal procedure established under Title
, Chapters
and

of the United States Code (Bankruptcy Code) whereby the debtor may seek relief from the claims of a creditor. h. Compromise - Acceptance of less than the full amount of the debt from the debtor in satisfaction of the debt. i. Contingency fees - Administrative costs assessed by Fiscal Service and/or private collection agencies for the successful enforced collection delinquent debt. Contingency fees are paid from amounts collected from the debtor. j. Cross-servicing - The process whereby agencies refer delinquent administrative (non-tax) debt to the Fiscal Service for enforced collection. k. Debt - An amount of money that has been determined by an appropriate federal official to be owed to the United States from a current employee, former employee or an entity. l. Debt collection - The recovery, in full or in part, of an administrative tax) debt owed to the IRS through the receipt of money, either in the form of a check, money order or by electronic means. m. Default - Failure to meet a ﬁnancial obligation. n. Delinquent - A debt that is not paid by the due date speciﬁed in the letter or for which payments are not received in compliance with the of an approved repayment agreement.
1.36 Administrative Accounting and Financial Management Reports

o. Disposable pay - The amount of an employee’s wages that remains after deductions from earnings of any amount required by law to be withheld. These deductions include, but are not limited to, FICA taxes, Medicare taxes and federal, state and local income taxes. They do not include dis- cretionary deductions such as ﬁnancial allotments and charitable contributions. p. Due process - The requirement to give the debtor notice of an tive (non-tax) debt and the opportunity to dispute the debt and intended collection action. q. Enforced salary offset - The process of collecting a percentage of an employee’s current salary to satisfy a delinquent administrative (non-tax) debt. r. Financial hardship - An inability to meet the basic living expenses for goods and services necessary for the survival of the debtor, their spouse and any dependents. s. Health insurance receivable - A debt established to recover advanced employee salary submitted by the IRS to the insurance carrier to pay an employee’s share of Federal Employee Health Beneﬁt (FEHB) premiums during a period of non-pay or insufficient pay status. t. Hearing Official - An Administrative Law Judge or other individual autho- rized to conduct a hearing and issue a ﬁnal decision in response to a request for a hearing. u. Interest - The amount assessed on delinquent debts to compensate the government for the time value of money owed and not paid when due; interest is accrued and assessed from the date of delinquency. Often referred to as additional interest. v. Lump sum payment - A single non-recurring payment to pay a debt in w. Overpayment - Any amount paid that is more than the amount owed to the employee and to which they are not entitled. x. Penalties - Punitive charges assessed on delinquent debts. The rate to assessed is set by law and is assessed on the portion of a debt delinquent more than

calendar days. y. Principal - An amount owed by the debtor, excluding interest, penalties, administrative costs, fees and prepaid charges. z. Private collection agency - A private-sector entity whose primary business is the collection of delinquent debts. aa. Proof of Debt- Document(s) of which a creditor submits details of its claim. ab. Repayment agreement - A written contract in which the debtor agrees pay the debt via periodic installments. ac. Reschedule - A change in the existing terms or conditions to facilitate repayment of a debt. ad. Restitution - Compensation to the United States for a loss, damage or injury. ae. Salary debt - A debt that occurs because of pay and leave actions, including debts resulting from beneﬁts activities. af. Salary offset - The process of collecting a percentage or set dollar amount of the employees’ current salary to repay a debt. ag. Treasury Offset Program (TOP) - A Fiscal Service program that offsets all eligible federal payments for repayment of delinquent debt.
(Non-tax) Debt Management 1.36.4
Wage garnishment
The process of withholding amounts for administrative (non
tax) debt from the debtor’s disposable non
federal wages and paying those amounts to the government in accordance with a withholding order. Waiver
In accordance with an appropriate statute, the cancellation, remission, forgiveness or non
recovery by the creditor agency of an ad
ministrative (non
tax) debt owed to that agency and generally initiated as a result of the debtor’s request. Waiver request
A petition seeking relief from paying an administrative (non
tax) debt.

1.36 Administrative Accounting and Management Reports
Employees may incur debts that arise as the result of pay and leave actions including but not limited to:

the employee’s regular salary. a. An ESP is collected from the employee’s next salary payment. b. Any ESP not repaid by the end of the year it was received is subject to income tax withholding and is reported on the debtor’s Form W-
, and Tax Statement. (
) Advanced leave is subject to repayment. See IRM
, Payment of Advanced Leave by Separating Employees and IRM
, Payment Advanced Leave While Currently Employed, for further information. (

) Salary overpayments are erroneous payments that arise from administrative discrepancies from: a. Time and attendance transactions. b. Payroll processing. c. Personnel actions by either the employee or the IRS. (

) Salary overpayments also include errors in processing federal employee beneﬁts that are unrelated to employee rights to continue or terminate coverage when the employee goes into a non-pay or insufficient pay status. See IRM
for FEHB premiums information. (
) Employees have a responsibility to notify the IRS of errors and may be required to repay salary overpayments, including those caused by the IRS. (

) The IRS notiﬁes the employee when it determines that a salary overpayment has occurred and requests repayment. Failure to remit payment or enter into an acceptable repayment agreement by the date speciﬁed in the debt letter result in the debt being considered delinquent. (
) If a salary overpayment is $

or less, the IRS may automatically collect the full amount from the employee’s next salary payment and a notice will be placed on the Statement of Earnings and Leave for the collection. If the employee is in a non-pay status, normal debt collection procedures will and they will be provided with notice of the debt. (
) An employee who receives an erroneous salary overpayment may request a waiver of repayment. See IRM
, Financial Accounting, Administrative Waiver, for more information.
Administrative (Non-tax) Debt Management
) Salary overpayments not repaid in the same year as received are considered taxable income and reported on Form W-
, Wage and Tax Statements, as plicable. (

) The Federal Employees Health Beneﬁts (FEHB) program provides health beneﬁts for federal employees. Both the employee and the IRS pay a portion of the premium amount with the employee’s portion of the premium being withheld from their salary each pay period. An employee may incur a debt when they cannot pay their share of the premium because the employee: a. Entered a non-pay status. b. Received insufficient pay to cover the FEHB premium amount. c. Experienced a life event that requires special processing. (

) Federal employees in a non-pay status or who receive salary that is to pay their share of the FEHB premium may elect to continue their for a period not to exceed one year during which time the employing agency may approve advanced pay to cover the employee’s share of the FEHB premium per
USC

(e). If advanced pay is necessary to cover the em- ployee’s share of their FEHB premium, the employee or former employee (if the employee does not return to pay status) is obligated to repay the IRS. (

) If the employee elects to continue coverage while in a leave without pay but not to pay their health insurance premiums on a current basis, the employee is indebted to the IRS for all payments made on their behalf. tion on the debt is made per

) Debts arising from travel transactions include: a. Travel advances - If a trip is canceled or postponed or the travel zation has expired, the debtor must repay the outstanding balance of advance not liquidated in the travel system. b. Travel overpayments and corrections to original travel vouchers - Post audit reviews are randomly conducted of e-travel vouchers from the tronic travel system to identify discrepancies. c. See IRM

) Debts arising from relocation transactions include: a. Relocation advances -The employee must repay the remaining balance when the employee’s relocation voucher does not liquidate the ing balance of each relocation travel segment. If the relocation is canceled, the employee is responsible for repaying the full amount of outstanding relocation. b. Service agreements - When an employee violates a service or tation agreement or fails to affect the transfer or appointment, the employee must reimburse the amount expended by the IRS. c. Transportation of household goods - When the weight of an employee’s household goods exceeds the maximum allowable limit, the employee must reimburse the IRS for the transportation costs and other charges the excess. Employees must reimburse the IRS for unauthorized performed by the mover or third-party service provider. See IRM IRS Relocation Travel Guide and IRM

, Relocation Services Program for additional information. d. Withholding Tax Allowance is calculated and applied to the employee’s relocation voucher and third-party payments made on the employee’s behalf. When the employee’s taxable income is below the Withholding Tax Allowance, the IRS determines the amount the employee must reimburse the IRS for the overpayment. e. Relocation overpayments and corrections to original relocation which are audited upon receipt. (

) A restitution debt occurs when a debtor is held liable for a loss incurred by IRS because of negligent, willful, unauthorized or illegal acts by an former employee, individual or entity that include: a. Theft, misuse or loss of government funds. b. False claims for services and travel. c. Illegal, unauthorized obligations and expenditures of government priations. d. Unauthorized use of government-owned or leased equipment, facilities, supplies and services for other than official or approved purposes. e. Lost, stolen, damaged or destroyed government property or equipment. f. Improper purchases made with the government purchase card. (
) The debtor is responsible for compensating the IRS for restitution debts. (
) For additional information about improper purchases, see the Employee Re- source Center website for the Restricted Purchase List. (

) Debts arising from vendor transactions include but are not limited to: a. IRS Grant Programs - If a recipient of funds from an IRS grant does not comply with the federal requirements, terms and conditions of the program, the funds must be paid back to the IRS. b. User Fee Programs - Participants that receive beneﬁts or services for a fee must pay all invoices in full by the due date. See IRM

, Financial Accounting, User Fees, for additional information. c. Contracted Goods and Services - Any payment made to a vendor for goods or service to be provided to the IRS must be repaid to the IRS if the terms and conditions of the contract are not fulﬁlled. See IRM Financial Accounting, Receipt and Acceptance, for additional (

) Delinquent debts are referred to Fiscal Service for collection through their Management Services and are collected through various means such as: a. Administrative Wage Garnishment. b. Credit Bureau Reporting. c. Treasury Offset Program (TOP). d. Referral to Private Collection Agencies. (
) Delinquent debtors are generally barred from receiving federal loans or loan guarantees until the debt is resolved. Internal Revenue Manual

Delinquent debts are referred to Fiscal Service for collection through their Debt Management Services and are collected through various means such as:
Administrative Accounting and Management Reports (
) Federal debt collection statutes require the IRS to provide employees and entities with debt letters and due process rights under the Debt Collection of
and the Debt Collection Improvement Act of

) The letter outlines the following information: a. The type, nature and amount of the debt. b. The payment due date to avoid the debt becoming delinquent. c. Payment instructions and the IRS point-of-contact. d. Repayment options available to the employee. e. IRS policies for accruing interest, administrative charges and delinquent debts. f. Instructions to dispute the amount or the existence of the debt. g. Instructions to request a review of the debt or inspect and copy IRS records related to the debt. h. Employee ﬁling instructions to petition for a salary offset hearing non-Treasury official, if applicable. i. Steps for requesting an internal review of the debt (paper hearing), if plicable. j. The collection actions IRS may take to enforce collection if the debt is paid by the payment due date. This includes commencing enforced offset for current employees, referring the debt to Fiscal Service for tion by offset or a private collection agency, reporting the debt to a reporting bureau or referring the debt to the Department of Justice k. Instructions for submitting a ﬁnancial hardship request. l. Instructions for requesting a waiver of the debt, if applicable. See IRM
, Financial Accounting, Administrative Waiver for additional tion regarding the waiver process. (
) A debt is delinquent if it has not been paid by the date speciﬁed in the debt letter. (
) If an employee enters into an applicable repayment agreement, the debt becomes delinquent when it has not been paid pursuant to the terms of the agreement. (

) If a debtor fails to respond to the debt letter, the debt is considered as of the date the original notice was mailed. Interest, administrative and penalties are added to the unpaid balance and the IRS will begin collection action. (

) The IRS assesses interest on a debt at the Current Value of Funds Rate in effect at the time the debt becomes delinquent unless the debt is paid in within the grace period. The Current Value of Funds Rate is based on the Treasury Tax and Loan Rate to the nearest whole percent. (
) Interest is assessed on the principal balance and the rate remains ﬁxed for duration of the debt without compounding. (
) The IRS assesses administrative charges, which represent the additional incurred by the IRS for handling and processing a delinquent debt. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
S

tion regarding the waiver process. (
) A debt is delinquent if it has not been paid by the date speciﬁed in the IRS’s debt letter. (
) If an employee enters into an applicable repayment agreement, the debt becomes delinquent when it has not been paid pursuant to the terms of the agreement. (

) If a debtor fails to respond to the debt letter, the debt is considered as of the date the original notice was mailed. Interest, administrative charges and penalties are added to the unpaid balance and the IRS will begin collection action. (

) The IRS assesses interest on a debt at the Current Value of Funds Rate in effect at the time the debt becomes delinquent unless the debt is paid in full within the grace period. The Current Value of Funds Rate is based on the Treasury Tax and Loan Rate to the nearest whole percent. (

The IRS assesses administrative charges, which represent the additional incurred by the IRS for handling and processing a delinquent debt.
(Non-tax) Debt Management 1.36.4

The penalty rate the IRS assesses is set by law, 31 USC 3717, Interest and penalty on Claims. Penalties accrue on all amounts (principal, interest and ad- ministrative charges) that remain outstanding for more than 90 calendar days. The penalty accrues from the date of delinquency.
Interest, administrative costs and penalties are not imposed for any period during which collection activity has been suspended pending agency

The IRS may waive the collection of interest, administrative charges and penalties when it determines that collection would be against equity and conscience or is not in the best interest of the government.
Each employee’s delinquent debt is subject to a 15% withholding from their disposable pay each pay period unless the employee:
a. Elects to repay the debt in a lump sum. b. Agrees in writing to a repayment agreement at a percentage greater than

%. c. Agrees in writing to a revised repayment schedule based on a ﬁnancial hardship determination. d. Requests a salary offset hearing before a non-Treasury hearing official and the hearing official orders that a lesser amount be withheld from the employee’s disposable pay. e. Requests a waiver or review of the debt.
Administrative Accounting and Management Reports (

) The IRS terminates enforced salary offset when the full amount of the debt collected or the employee separates from the IRS. However, after the employee separates from the IRS (either voluntarily or involuntarily), the imputes a lump sum deduction exceeding

% of disposable pay from any ﬁnal salary payments, which might include accrued leave, etc., to satisfy debt. If the debt is not satisﬁed with the lump sum payment, the bill must paid in full by the employee or it will be considered delinquent and referred Fiscal Service for collection action. (
) The Digital Accountability and Transparency Act of
requires agencies refer all non-tax debts or claims owed to the government that are to Fiscal for more than
calendar days for cross-servicing to the Department of Treasury, Fiscal Service. (
) An administrative (non-tax) debt is eligible for referral to Fiscal Service if delinquent debt is legally enforceable and greater than $
including administrative fees and interest. (

) When the IRS refers a debt to Fiscal Service for enforced collection, Fiscal Service assesses contingency fees and deducts them from amounts from the debtor. The balance of the payment is applied to the delinquent using the order described in IRM
, Application of Payments. (

) The IRS does not refer a debt to Fiscal Service if: a. A waiver request is pending. b. The debtor has ﬁled for bankruptcy protection or the debt has been discharged by bankruptcy proceeding. c. The debtor is deceased. (
) Information on the Fiscal Service debt collection program is available on Fiscal Service website. (

) When a debt is referred to Fiscal Service, the IRS is certifying in writing, the penalty of perjury, that to the best of their knowledge and belief that: a. The debt is valid and is not subject to any circumstances that legally preclude collection. b. There are no pending appeals. c. The debtor has been given the required notice of due process. (

) Fiscal Service uses several debt collection methods: a. Mailing letters and following up with phone calls. b. Negotiating payment agreement options. c. Reporting debts to credit bureaus. d. Referring debts to the Treasury Offset Program. e. Referring debts to the Administrative Wage Garnishment Program. f. Referring cases to private collection agencies and the DOJ. (

) Fiscal Service maintains debt balance information, collects the funds paid the debtor and returns the funds to the IRS for proper processing, and application to the debt. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

1.36 Administrative Accounting and Financial Management Reports
1.36.4.8.1 (05-04-2020) Cross-Servicing Program
When a debt is referred to Fiscal Service, the IRS is certifying in writing, under the penalty of perjury, that to the best of their knowledge and belief that:
(Non-tax) Debt Management
) Fiscal Service charges contingency fees for its incurred costs related to Cross-Servicing Program. (
) Additional fees are assessed when the debt is: a. Collected through the Treasury Offset Program. b. Referred to private collection agencies. c. Referred to the DOJ. (
) When Fiscal Service successfully offsets or otherwise collects all or part of debt, the collected amount is applied in the following order:
Contingency fees.
Penalties.
Administrative costs (other than contingency fees).
Interest.
Principal. (
) Fiscal Service refers debts to the DOJ for litigation when aggressive activity has been attempted and the debt cannot be compromised, or terminated. (
) The Treasury Offset Program (TOP) is a centralized offset program, tered by Fiscal Service, to collect delinquent debts and child support Offset Program owed to federal and state agencies. (
) When a debt is referred to TOP for collection, Fiscal Service is authorized seize federal payments due to the debtor and apply it to the debt balance. (

) Federal law limits the amount that may be withheld from some types of payments that are subject to certain exemptions and limitations. Examples federal payments eligible for offset include: a. Federal IRS tax refunds. b. Retirement payments issued by the OPM. c. Travel advances and reimbursements. d. Certain federal beneﬁt payments including Social Security beneﬁts than Supplemental Security income), Railroad Retirement beneﬁts than tier

) and Black Lung (part B beneﬁts). e. Grant payments. f. Vendor payments. g. Active military and military retirement payments. h. Other federal payments that are not exempt by law or by action of Secretary of the Treasury. (
) Fiscal Service charges a fee to cover its costs for collections through TOP. fee is collected from each offset. (
) For debtors with multiple debts, Fiscal Service applies the collections to debtor in the following order:
IRS income tax debts.
Child support debts.
Federal non-tax debts.
State income tax debts.

) A private collection agency remits any collections received to Fiscal Fiscal Service remits the funds to the IRS with supporting detailed debt mation. Private collection agencies net fees for collecting debts against the amount collected before remitting the funds to Fiscal Service. (

) Administrative Wage Garnishment (AWG) is a collection tool that Fiscal Service uses to collect delinquent debt from: a. Federal employees who have private sector part-time jobs. b. Non-federal employees. (
) Debtors that object to garnishment of their wages can request a hearing Fiscal Service. (
) Additional information on Administrative Wage Garnishment is available on Fiscal Service website. (
) The IRS is generally prohibited from pursuing further collection action due an automatic stay when a debtor ﬁles for bankruptcy protection effective date of the ﬁling of bankruptcy. (
) Fiscal Service returns previously referred delinquent debts to the IRS when they determine the debtor has ﬁled for bankruptcy protection. (
) If a debt is discharged by the bankruptcy court, the IRS is precluded from pursuing collection on the debt incurred by the debtor. (

(Non-tax) Debt Management
) The IRS uses all available collection tools described in this IRM to collect unpaid debts owed by a former employee. (
) An employee’s ﬁnal salary payment and lump sum leave payment may be offset if the employee does not satisfy the debt. The ﬁnal salary payment be delayed or reduced by the amount owed. The
% disposable pay limit does not apply. If the entire debt is not satisﬁed, the IRS will establish a able for the remaining balance and begins collection activity. (
) When an employee retires with an existing salary debt, the NFC notiﬁes to garnish retirement beneﬁts. (
) For additional information: a. See “Schedule of Separation Actions” in the Retirement chapter of Document

The IRS is unable to collect any substantial amount through its own efforts or through the efforts of others or the debtor is deceased or is able to be located. The debt cannot be substantiated.
